homePage.title: AI Agents Learning Platform
homePage.subtitle: The core concepts of AI agents for building intelligent systems

understand.title: Understand
understand.description: Learn the 4+2 framework that powers every AI agent: a 4-step process (Perception, Reasoning, Planning, Execution) plus 2 support systems (Memory and Tools)

practice.title: Practice
practice.description: Map agent boundaries, build circuits using the 4+2 model, run simulations, and debug failures through hands-on activities

build.title: Build
build.description: Design and test your own agent using the 4+2 framework, evaluate its performance, and learn to identify common failure patterns

ready.title: Ready to Begin?
ready.description: This is designed to teach you how AI agents work by breaking them down into simple parts. You'll learn that agents follow a 4-step process: they read incoming information (Perception), figure out what it means (Reasoning), decide what to do (Planning), and then do it (Execution). Along the way, they use two support systems: Memory to remember past experiences, and Tools to take actions in the world. You'll build your own simple agent, watch it run step-by-step, and learn to spot common problems when things go wrong. No coding required.

homePage.methodology: Designed with cognitive apprenticeship, retrieval practice, and metacognitive calibration to maximize learning outcomes

primer.title: How AI Agents Work
primer.subtitle: The 4+2 model. The fundamental pattern behind every AI agent

intro.heading: The 4+2 Model
intro.description: Good AI Agents are designed to behave like a smart assistant that follows the same basic cycle over and over: it reads information, figures out what it means, decides what to do, then does it. Two key elements enable this cycle: a **memory** system that preserves context across interactions, and a diverse **toolkit** of capabilities they can leverage to solve problems and complete tasks.

runLoop.title: The 4-Step Run Loop (happens in order, every time)

perception.label: Read the Data
perception.name: Perception
perception.description: Gathers all available data from the user and environment, organizing it into a usable format.

reasoning.label: Decide What It Means
reasoning.name: Reasoning
reasoning.description: Interprets the data to understand the underlying intent and updates its internal model of the world.

planning.label: Make a Plan
planning.name: Planning
planning.description: Formulates a specific sequence of operations and tool-calls to achieve the goal.

execution.label: Take Action
execution.name: Execution
execution.description: Executes the plan to produce the final output or interact with the environment.

memory.label: Memory (Learning)
memory.description: Like a notebook the agent carries â€” it can look up past information or write down new things at ANY point during the 4 steps

tools.label: Tools & UI (Interaction)
tools.description: Like a toolbox or phone to call for help â€” the agent can use tools or show messages at ANY point during the 4 steps

crossCutting.title: Why are these "Supporting" not "Steps"?
crossCutting.description: Memory and Tools are supporting components, not steps in the loop. The 4 steps represent a sequential process that runs in a fixed order, while Memory and Tools are on-demand resources. Like a 'workbench,' any step in the process can access them at any time to retrieve information or perform a specific function.

demo.title: Real Example: Health Coach Agent
demo.subtitle: Let's watch an AI health coach go through the 4 steps with a real user's fitness data

perception.label: Step 1: Read the Data
perception.example: The agent receives messy sensor data like "HR:72,68,75,71|STEPS:8500" and organizes it into: Heart rate = [72, 68, 75, 71 BPM], Steps = 8,500

reasoning.label: Step 2: Decide What It Means
reasoning.example: The agent thinks: "Is 71 BPM healthy? (Yes, it's between 60-100.) Did they meet their goal of 7,000 steps? (Yes, 8,500 > 7,000.) This person is doing well!"

planning.label: Step 3: Make a Plan
planning.example: The agent decides: "Since everything looks healthy, I should encourage them to keep it up rather than warning them about problems."

execution.label: Step 4: Take Action
execution.example: The agent sends the message: "Great job! Your heart rate is steady at 71 BPM and you exceeded your 7,000 step goal. Keep up the excellent work!"

memory.label: ðŸ§  Memory (used during Step 2)
memory.example: While deciding what the data means, the agent checks its notebook: "Last week this user averaged 65 BPM, so 71 is normal for them."

tools.label: ðŸ”§ Tools (used during Step 4)
tools.example: To send the message, the agent uses the notification tool â€” like using a phone to text the user.

check1.question: In our health coach example, the agent decided to "send encouragement" rather than "send a warning." Which step made this choice?
check1.explanation: Correct! Planning is Step 3, where the agent chooses WHICH specific action to take. Reasoning (Step 2) figured out the user was healthy, but Planning (Step 3) decided that meant sending encouragement rather than a warning or doing nothing.

check2.question: The notification tool that sends messages to users â€” is this a "step" in the 4-step loop, or a "supporting system"?
check2.explanation: Right! The notification tool is part of the Tools supporting system. It's not a step itself â€” it's a resource that Step 4 (Execution) uses to carry out the planned action. Think of it like a hammer in a toolbox: not a step in building, but a tool you use during the building step.

complete.title: Perfect! You Understand the 4+2 Model
complete.description: You've learned how every AI agent follows the same fundamental pattern

remember.title: Key Takeaways:
remember.point1: Every agent does 4 steps in order: Read â†’ Understand â†’ Choose â†’ Act
remember.point2: Memory & Tools aren't steps â€” they're resources any step can use
remember.point3: Now you'll practice sorting real agent capabilities into these categories

workedExample.title: Learn From an Expert's Thinking
workedExample.subtitle: Watch how an expert decides where each capability belongs â€” and learn from common mistakes
workedExample.cardLabel: What the agent needs to do:
workedExample.mightThink: Many beginners incorrectly think this goes in

tip.title: Pro Tip
tip.description: Don't get fooled by keywords! Focus on the ACTION. Is it reading input? Understanding meaning? Choosing what to do? Or actually doing it?

parseSensor.explanation: "Parse" means to read and organize. This takes messy sensor data like 'HR:72,68,75' and turns it into clean numbers the agent can understand. That's Step 1 (Perception) â€” reading and organizing input. Think: Is it READING data? Yes!

thresholdCheck.text: Check if heart rate is within healthy range
thresholdCheck.explanation: This is figuring out what the numbers MEAN. Is 72 BPM good or bad? That requires understanding health ranges. That's Step 2 (Reasoning) â€” understanding the significance. Think: Is it DECIDING what the data means? Yes!

chooseAction.text: Decide whether to encourage or alert the user
chooseAction.explanation: Now the agent knows the user is healthy, but should it send encouragement, a warning, or stay quiet? This is Step 3 (Planning) â€” choosing WHICH action to take. Think: Is it CHOOSING between different possible actions? Yes!

sendMessage.explanation: This is actually sending the message to the user's phone. It's Step 4 (Execution) â€” carrying out the chosen action. Think: Is it DOING the actual task? Yes!

storeBaseline.text: Remember user's baseline heart rate for future comparisons
storeBaseline.explanation: "Storing" and "remembering" are memory operations. This isn't a step in the 4-step loop â€” it's using the Memory supporting system (like writing in a notebook). Any of the 4 steps could do this. Think: Is it storing information for later? Yes â†’ Memory!

callApi.text: Fetch user's calendar to avoid alerts during meetings
callApi.explanation: "Fetching" from an API means using an external tool. This isn't a step â€” it's using the Tools supporting system. Any of the 4 steps might need calendar data. Think: Is it using an external service or tool? Yes â†’ Tools!

calendarNearMiss.text: Schedule a follow-up check for tomorrow
calendarNearMiss.explanation: TRICKY! The word "schedule" makes you think Planning, but look closer: this is USING the calendar tool to CREATE an appointment. It's Interaction (Tools), not Planning. Planning would be DECIDING to schedule, but the actual ACT of scheduling uses a tool.

model.title: How agents work: a 4-step run loop + 2 supporting systems (4+2)

runLoop.title: 4-Step Run Loop
runLoop.description: Read the data (Perception) â†’ Decide what it means (Reasoning) â†’ Make a plan (Planning) â†’ Do the step (Execution)

memory.title: Memory (Learning)
memory.description: The agent's notesâ€”any stage can read or update them

tools.title: Tools & UI (Interaction)
tools.description: How the agent acts in the worldâ€”any stage can call a tool or show something to a user

model.crossCutting: Cross-cutting: available to any stage rather than a step in the line

home.title: AI Agents Learning Platform
home.subtitle: Master AI agents from core concepts to building your ownâ€”through interactive, pedagogically-designed activities

understand.title: Understand
understand.description: Learn the six core processes that make AI agents work: Learning, Interaction, Perception, Reasoning, Planning, and Execution

practice.title: Practice
practice.description: Map agent boundaries, build circuits, run simulations, and debug failures through hands-on activities

classification.title: Phase 1: Apply What You've Learned
classification.description: Now it's your turn! Sort these agent capabilities into the 6 categories. Remember: 4 steps happen in order (Perception â†’ Reasoning â†’ Planning â†’ Execution), while Memory and Tools are available anytime.
classification.independentDescription: Sort capabilities into the 6 processes and explain your thinking â€” this helps you learn!
classification.dragInstruction: Drag each capability from below into the correct category above, then explain your reasoning
classification.explainPlaceholder: Why does this belong here? (Tip: Mention what ACTION this performs)
classification.explanationRequired: Please explain each choice â€” this helps you understand WHY, not just memorize WHERE
classification.continueDescription: You've mastered classification! Review your results and continue
classification.crossCuttingHint: Remember: This isn't a step â€” it's a resource available to ALL steps
classification.incorrectFeedback: Think about the core action: Is it reading, understanding, choosing, doing, remembering, or using tools?

hints.learning: Hint: Memory/Learning isn't a step in the loop â€” it's like a notebook any step can write in or read from
hints.interaction: Hint: Tools/Interaction isn't a step in the loop â€” it's like a toolbox any step can reach for when needed

accessibility.instructions: Keyboard: {{tab}} to navigate all elements, {{arrowUpDown}} for quick navigation within sections, {{spaceEnter}} to grab/drop cards, {{escape}} to cancel

announcements.dropped: Dropped {{item}} into {{process}}. The card is now in {{process}} and can be tabbed to or re-grabbed if needed.
announcements.navigatedToZone: Navigated to {{process}} drop zone. Press {{enter}} to drop.
announcements.focusedOnZone: Focused on {{process}} drop zone. Press {{enter}} to drop.

guided.title: Practice with Help: Start Simple
guided.description: Let's practice with just 2 processes that are opposites: Perception (reading input) vs Execution (taking action). These are the easiest to tell apart!
guided.dragInstruction: Drag each item to the correct box. Click a starter phrase if you're stuck on the explanation.
guided.sortAllItems: Please sort all items before checking â€” try your best guess!
guided.contrastiveHint: Quick Test: Ask yourself â€” Is this about GETTING information IN (Perception) or SENDING actions OUT (Execution)? Reading = IN, Doing = OUT.

boundaryMap.title: Phase 2: Boundary Mapping
boundaryMap.description: Map the agent's environment, tools, and data flows to understand system boundaries
boundaryMap.canvasDescription: Place elements and connect them to processes by clicking an element, then clicking a process
boundaryMap.selectFirst: Select an element on the canvas first
boundaryMap.clickToConnect: Click a process to connect the selected element

feedback.needMoreElements: Please place at least {{count}} elements on the canvas to continue
feedback.needMoreConnections: Please create at least {{count}} connections to processes to continue
feedback.missingProcesses: Please connect elements to these core processes: {{processes}}
feedback.needSensorToPerception: Connect at least one Sensor element to Perception (sensors provide input data)
feedback.needExecutionToTool: Connect Execution to at least one API, Tool, or UI element (execution needs to interact with the world)
feedback.success: Great work! Your boundary map is complete

boundaryMap.completeRequirements: Complete the mapping requirements above to continue to Phase 3

noisyInput.name: Noisy Sensor Data
noisyInput.description: Heart rate readings fluctuate Â±15 BPM, simulating sensor noise or measurement error
noisyInput.tooltip: Adds Â±15 BPM jitter to heart rate readings

reducedActivity.name: Reduced Step Count
reducedActivity.description: Daily steps are reduced by 800, testing threshold logic for borderline activity levels

missingTool.name: Missing Notification Tool
missingTool.description: The sendNotification tool is unavailable, preventing the agent from alerting the user
missingTool.tooltip: Removes the sendNotification tool from available tools

staleMemory.name: Stale Memory State
staleMemory.description: Agent's memory is cleared, losing all context from previous steps

assessment.title: Phase 5: Assessment & Review
assessment.description: Review your performance across all phases and identify areas for growth
assessment.excellentCalibrationDesc: Your confidence levels closely match your actual performance. This indicates strong metacognitive awareness.
assessment.strongClassificationDesc: You've demonstrated solid understanding of the six agent processes.
assessment.improveExplanationsDesc: Try to provide more detailed reasoning that connects the item to the process's core function.

exitCheck.title: Final Understanding Check
exitCheck.description: Answer these questions to confirm your grasp of the 4+2 model

q1.question: Which activity belongs to the run loop vs the rails?

q2.question: Which step in the run loop chooses the action?

q3.question: Where is the habit streak stored?

feedbackLoops.definition: Mechanisms that allow the agent to learn from outcomes and adjust future behavior
feedbackLoops.example: After a failed action, the agent updates its strategy for similar situations

adaptation.definition: The agent's ability to modify its behavior based on new information or changing conditions
adaptation.example: Adjusting recommendations when user preferences change

memory.definition: Storage and retrieval of past interactions, decisions, and learned patterns

welcome.title: Your First Agent is Ready!
welcome.message: Great! The pipeline shows a working Health Coach agent. Click 'Run Demo' to watch it help a real user with their fitness data.
welcome.tip: As it runs, you'll see exactly how the 4 steps work together, plus when Memory ðŸ§  or Tools ðŸ”§ get used

firstRun.title: Time for Your First Run!
firstRun.message: Your Health Coach is set up perfectly. Click 'Run Demo' and watch carefully as it goes through each step with real fitness data.
firstRun.tip: Follow along: Step 1 reads raw data â†’ Step 2 understands it â†’ Step 3 chooses action â†’ Step 4 does it. The icons show when Memory ðŸ§  or Tools ðŸ”§ are used!

successFirst.title: ðŸŽ‰ Success! Your Agent Helped Someone!
successFirst.message: Perfect! The agent read fitness data, understood the user was healthy, and sent encouragement. Did you notice the ðŸ§  and ðŸ”§ icons showing when Memory and Tools were used?
successFirst.tip: Now experiment: swap different blocks to see how they handle data differently. Each block is like a different strategy â€” some are stricter, some more flexible!

changeBlock.title: Experiment Time!
changeBlock.message: Each block uses different logic. Try swapping them to learn the trade-offs â€” like how 'Rule Classifier' is stricter than 'Threshold Check'.
changeBlock.tip: Watch what changes: Does it store different things in Memory ðŸ§ ? Call different Tools ðŸ”§? This teaches you how small changes affect the whole system!

failureRecovery.title: Learning from Errors
failureRecovery.message: The agent hit a problem â€” this is valuable! Check the error message to see exactly which step failed and why.
failureRecovery.tip: Debug like a pro: Which step failed? What was it trying to do? Was it missing data from Memory ðŸ§  or couldn't find a Tool ðŸ”§? This teaches real debugging!

withFailures.title: Testing Real Problems
withFailures.message: Smart! You're testing how your agent handles real-world issues like broken sensors or missing tools. Watch how it adapts (or doesn't)!
withFailures.tip: Each failure tests different parts: noisy data tests Step 1 (Perception), missing tools test Step 4 (Execution), stale memory tests the Memory system ðŸ§ !

tryFailure.title: Great work!
tryFailure.message: You've seen how the 4-step loop handles normal operation. Try toggling failure modes to see how each step responds to errors.
tryFailure.tip: Watch which steps tap into Memory ðŸ§  (Learning) and which call Tools ðŸ”§ (Interaction). These supporting systems work with any step in the loop!

normalDay.name: Normal Active Day
normalDay.description: Healthy activity levels with clean sensor data

borderlineActivity.name: Borderline Activity
borderlineActivity.description: Just below activity thresholdâ€”tests edge cases

parse.name: Parse Wearables
parse.description: Extract raw heart rate and step count from sensor data

smooth.name: Smooth Wearables
smooth.description: Average readings to reduce sensor noise and outliers

threshold.name: Threshold Check
threshold.description: Simple rule: Active if steps â‰¥ 8000 and HR â‰¥ 90

ruleBased.name: Rule Classifier
ruleBased.description: Strict criteria: steps â‰¥ 10000 and HR â‰¥ 100 for active

daily.name: Daily Planner
daily.description: Create today's response: congratulate if active, nudge if not

weekly.name: Weekly Planner
weekly.description: Plan weekly trends and suggest long-term habits

notify.name: Send Notification
notify.description: Deliver push notification with encouragement or nudge

message.excellent: Amazing work! You exceeded your goals!
message.active: Great job hitting your step goal!
message.nudge: You can do it! Just a few more steps to reach your goal.

message.rest: Your heart rate is elevated. Please rest and consult a doctor if this continues.
message.lightActivity: Your heart rate is slightly elevated. Consider light activity only.
message.congratulate: Great job! Your metrics look healthy.
message.encourage: Your health metrics are good - you can safely increase activity!

consent.title: Save Your Learning Progress?
consent.description: We can save your progress in your browser so you can pick up right where you left off next time you visit.
consent.noPersonalData: No personal data collected - everything stays private in your browser
consent.yourChoice: You can change this choice anytime. If you decline, you'll start fresh each visit.
